title: Is “Gluten-Free” Enough for Celiac Disease?

content: Reading packaged food labels is a key part of navigating a gluten-free diet for celiac disease, but it can get tricky. Scanning ingredient lists for gluten sources is one way to judge product safety, as are various types of gluten-free labels.
While gluten-free labeling is increasingly common, it doesn’t always accurately reflect what’s in the package. Understanding what’s behind labeling is important to avoid hidden gluten in your diet.

Food manufacturers in the U.S. aren’t required to indicate whether their product contains gluten besides listing the ingredients. Any additional gluten labeling is entirely voluntary choice. However, with the prevalence of celiac disease and many consumers following a gluten-free diet, a lot of companies choose to do so.
You may encounter several labeling scenarios with packaged foods:
bullets: Manufacturer gluten-free labels: May look like the words “gluten-free” or “free of gluten.” If a U.S. manufacturer includes this, it must legally meet the FDA’s gluten-free criteria, which is less than 20 parts per million (the general safety limit for celiac disease). There isn’t a standard “gluten-free” FDA label, so it’s up to companies to print words or symbols to show this. Gluten-free labels can be placed on any food or beverage product including naturally gluten-free items like bottled water.

Gluten-free certifications: Denoted by a distinct logo on the package, indicates a third party certification group has verified the product is 100% gluten-free. These independent organizations collaborate with food manufacturers to assess gluten contamination using similar or stricter standards than those of the FDA. They typically examine both the food and production process to ensure gluten is absent.

No gluten-free labeling is common on naturally gluten-free or single-ingredient products, such as milk or fresh fruit, as they’re assumed gluten-safe. However, products with longer ingredient lists may not be assumed 100% gluten-free. Scanning the ingredient list for sources of gluten as well as looking for a wheat disclaimer may give initial clues that there could still be gluten in an unlabeled product.

Wheat labeling is mandatory for all U.S. food products containing wheat, one of the nine major food allergens. The FDA requires an allergen label stating “contains wheat” or the word “wheat” noted in the ingredient list. This label helps identify a product that contains gluten, since gluten is a protein in wheat. However, it’s possible for some wheat products to be stripped of gluten, so it’s not guaranteed. Additionally, wheat labeling doesn’t cover rye or barley, which also contain gluten, so wheat-free is not necessarily gluten-free.

sections.heading: Gluten-Free Mislabeling
content: If a food manufacturer chooses to label their product as gluten-free, the FDA requires this claim to be truthful. However, mistakes do occur and get spotted by consumers more often than you’d think. This is more prevalent with products that are self-labeled by the manufacturer as gluten-free versus those that have gone through independent gluten-free certification. A variety of “gluten-free” labeled products have been found to have gluten-containing ingredients despite the manufacturer’s claim. Spotting a gluten-free label is a good starting place for selecting a celiac-friendly product, but it doesn’t necessarily tell the whole story.

Navigating the various labeling scenarios can be a juggle, but they offer clues for finding safe products. Certified gluten-free products are generally more reliable, while manufacturer claims may require further scrutiny. A product without any gluten-free labeling could be naturally free of gluten or may include a more complex ingredient list that requires a careful read through. Ultimately, choosing a food product is a contextual decision and is based on your specific dietary needs. When in doubt, find an alternative you feel comfortable with.
